values: Would you like to know more?

Begin by building the Happy Path of Hand-offs, and assign the metrics, causes and solutions to each step or to the overall process as applicable. 

For more details on how to do this, please visit 'Getting started on Open Orbit' on our support page. 

We use this framework to calculate the effort saved. Shall I go on?
So you want to look at the business case for deploying RPA on a given process. This analysis has the following factors, and it is recommended, though not essential to work on them in this order.

options: Transaction volumes and Effort per transaction analysed on Open Orbit workbench
Cost of fixing the dependencies identified in the readiness tests on Open Orbit
Potential to leverage across other parts of the business
Overall cost-benefit case based on cost of effort saved, cost of robot licencing and cost of robot training

values: When looking at RPA feasibility or readiness for a process there are four basic tests which you may work on in any order. Which test would you like to learn about?

options: Is the process reasonably effective and efficient for example from a lean six sigma perspective, and is it digitised enough
Is the process well-documented and rule-based
Is the process stable and unaffected by other inflight initiatives in the business
Does the process involve external risks to consider before you automate using RPA

values: Alright! Lets begin with readiness of a process.

There are three steps to calculating effort saved. Firstly, use the Work Type feature to separate “In good order” and “Not in Good Order” volumes; Robots will typically save effort on the former, and not on the latter.
Alright! Thanks for your time! We take your feedback seriously

On the Open Orbit workbench, you will use two features for RPA readiness assessment -
 the symptom-cause-remedy analysis, and the happy path of hand-offs. You will identify the key barriers to automation – avoidable hand-offs; avoidable exceptions and rework; and non-digital inputs and outputs. For more details, please visit 'Getting started on Open Orbit' on our support page.

options: I want to learn about other tests for RPA readiness
I want to know about building a business case now

values:
The overall cost-benefit case for RPA on a given process is determined by comparing the cost of labour saved with the cost of licencing and training a robot. The cost of labour saved is in turn determined by the unit cost of labour, multiplied by the estimated effort to be saved. The licencing, training and unit labour cost are simple input parameters, and the effort to be saved is estimated using the analysis of Transaction Volumes and Effort Saved per transaction, on Open Orbit’s Happy Path of Hand-offs feature.
Open Orbit can provide you with a worked example. If you have been following the default path using the 'next' button this completes the analysis.

options: I'd like to learn about other factors in the business case
I want to know about tests for RPA readiness now

values: Cost of fixing the dependencies identified in the readiness tests on Open Orbit: While conducting readiness tests, we check for process effectiveness and efficiency, along with level of digital input and output. Along the way, we may identify dependencies which when solved will enable automation. These are recorded as “Solutions” and “Solution Checklists” on the Open Orbit workbench. Against each Solution Checklist item, we recommend you now record the estimated cost of implementing that improvement. For more details on using the Open Orbit workbench, please visit 'Getting started on Open Orbit' on our support page.

options: I'd like to learn about other factors in the business case
I want to know about tests for RPA readiness now

values: Potential to leverage across other parts of the business: The potential for re-use across the business is a matter of context and needs to be decided by subject matter experts. For example, identifying an existing customer, or on-boarding a new customer, are commonly used across many different parts of the business and investing in improving these is more likely to be leveraged widely than processes which are unique to a given area of business. Open Orbit custom fields can be configured to help you record your decision.

options: I'd like to learn about other factors in the business case
I want to know about tests for RPA readiness now

values: Transaction volumes and Effort per transaction: Open Orbit’s Happy Path feature helps you frame and analyse the effort that can be saved through automation by clearly identifying the proportion of transaction volume and touch time that can actually be automated, as opposed to overall volumes and touch time. Would you like me to continue?

Is the process well-documented and rule-based: Robots are not good with judgment or unclear instructions. So if there is human judgment involved, or if the current process is not clearly defined, that needs to be dealt with first. If the process fails this test but you believe that this can be rectified, you may note this as a dependency and move on as if this will be fixed. Based on other tests, you can then decide if it is worth investing the effort to document the process, and codify the rules. Open Orbit custom fields can be configured to help you record your decision.

options: I want to learn about other tests for RPA readiness
I want to know about building a business case now

values: Is the process reasonably effective and efficient for example from a lean six sigma perspective, and is it digitised enough: The structure required to conduct this analysis is provided in Open Orbit's  Diagnostic Map, Fishbone and Performance Gap reports. Open Orbit can also guide you on how to achieve RPA readiness, should the process fail this test initially. Should I continue?

Does the process involve external risks to consider before you automate using RPA: Robots cannot hold certifications, licenses or take the heat when something goes wrong, only people can. So if the work requires certified or licenced staff, or is likely to create reputational or regulatory risk, then you may want to defer this process till the business has implemented RPA in other processes and has developed some experience in dealing with risks that emerge along the way. Open Orbit custom fields can be configured to help you record your decision.

options: I want to learn about other tests for RPA readiness
I want to know about building a business case now

values: Is the process stable and unaffected by other inflight initiatives in the business: Robots are effective and efficient but also expensive to program. If the instructions are likely to change soon or change often, it may be advisable to wait for that change to settle down first. There is no work-around to this test – we recommend deferring the RPA work on this process if it changes frequently or is about to change significantly. Open Orbit custom fields can be configured to help you record your decision.

options: I want to learn about other tests for RPA readiness
I want to know about building a business case now

values: Secondly, make sure Volumes and Touch Times of transactions “In Good Order” for the steps that can be automated, are available. If not, they need to be measured to enable the calculation of effort saved. If measurement is not feasible, you will need to make a judgment call on whether you can proceed with anecdotal estimates or not.
Ok!

Before implementing RPA, we need to answer two questions - Is RPA feasible for this process; and will it actually be beneficial? The former identifies readiness, dependencies and risks and the latter focuses on the business case. Which one would you like to start with?

Thirdly and finally, if multiple consecutive steps can be automated, then calculate a sum-product of volume and touch time for “In good order” cases across those steps. Open orbit can provide you with worked examples if required.

options: I'd like to learn about other factors in the business case
I want to know about tests for RPA readiness now

values: Perhaps it would be better for you to contact us in person
See you later! Did you find this helpful?
You seem to want to know about the potential to leverage across other parts of the business. This is one of the four components of a business case for RPA. Is this what you meant?

Would you mind clarifying what you meant? What do you want to know about? Do you want to know if it feasible to use RPA for a particular process or if it is beneficial to do so. The former identifies readiness, dependencies and risks through the use of four tests. The latter focuses on the business case by thinking about four key factors.

options: I want to learn about tests for RPA readiness
I want to know about building a business case now

values: It looks like you want to see if a process is effective and efficient enough. This is one of the four critical tests for process readiness for RPA. Is this what you meant?
You seem to want to know about transaction volumes, effort per transaction and effort saved due to automation. This is one of the four components of a business case for RPA. Is this what you meant?

It looks like you want to see if a process is stable and remains unchanged despite other business activity. This is one of the four critical tests for process readiness for RPA. Is this what you meant?
Would you like to learn about the four components in a business case for RPA?
You seem to want to know about the cost of fixing dependencies. This is one of the four components of a business case for RPA. Is this what you meant?
It looks like you want to see if a process has risks regarding regulatory or reputational exposure. This is one of the four critical tests for process readiness for RPA. Is this what you meant?
It looks like you want to see if a process is well documented and rules based. This is one of the four critical tests for process readiness for RPA. Is this what you meant?
Would you like to learn about the four tests we use to check for RPA readiness? These mainly focus on identifying readiness, dependencies an risks.
You seem to want to know about the overall Cost Benefit Analysis. This is one of the four components of a business case for RPA. Is this what you meant?

Welcome to Open Orbit's interactive tool for RPA (Robotic Process Automation) assessments. You can choose from the options provided. You can also respond with 'next' to go down a default path, 'bye' if you're done at any stage or 'restart' if you want to do so. If you want to know about a specific idea you can just type in some key phrases. Are you ready?
